title: The New Ford's Theatre Visitor Experience

json.text: (music plays)
In the words of David McCullough,
the story of the real Abraham Lincoln has receded so far into the nation's
memory,
that what remains seems a little more than a dream.
The new Ford's Theatre visitor experience will enable 21st century Americans
to know the living Lincoln, to immerse themselves in the extraordinary process
a personal, political, and moral growth that makes Lincoln a
leader for the ages.
(music plays)
Lincoln's presidency is bracketed by assassination plots
and epic rail journeys.  It is hard to imagine
any President taking office under more discouraging circumstances.
As visitors enter, we recreate those early traumatic events
in exhibits that lead to the basement museum.  The sounds of a busy train
station surround visitors as they make their way through the Lincoln railcar
at the museum entrance.  We see the President-elect
traveling in disguise as an influent,  hoping to fool conspirators who planned
to murder him
as he changes trains in Baltimore.  Those who can't navigate the steps
will be able to reach the same area by elevator.  All visitors will first be met
with a large three-dimensional unfinished capitol dome,
a metaphor for an America that may or may not be permanently broken.
The date is March 4th, 1861
and a multi-screen video presentation introduces us to the storm of troubles
confronting the new President.
Seven Southern states have already seceded from the Union.
Southern guns are trained on Fort Sumter in Charleston Harbor
and an anxious North looks for guidance to a leader who has never administered
anything larger
than a two-man law office.  Northern armies may be slow to arrive to defend the
beleaguered capital,
not so an army of northern office seekers
here brought to life as they wait impatiently outside Lincoln's White House
Office.
They parade past an exhibit on the making of his cabinet,
an early indicator that this seemingly inexperienced prairie lawyer and
one-term congressman
has hidden reserves of political shrewdness.
The spring of 1861 presents the first
real turning point in the Lincoln presidency.  Following South Carolina's
attack on Fort Sumter,
the president summons 75,000 volunteers,
declares a blockade of the South, and suspends the ancient privilege and
constitutional right
of Habeas corpus.  He says he finds it necessary to suspend a single clause in
the Constitution
if he is to have any hope of saving the rest of the document.
A brief video highlights Lincoln's pungent observation
that while it is sometimes necessary to sacrifice some limbs to save a life,
it is never wise to sacrifice a life to save a limb.
Nearby is the war room.  Behind the president's desk, a telescope
looks out over Arlington hills bristling with  rebel activity.
The centerpiece of the exhibit is the President's desk, the top of which is
actually a touchscreen,
allowing visitors to look over Lincoln's shoulder at a constantly
changing screen of dispatches from the front
critical telegrams, letters to and from the public,
speech drafts, and congressional inquiries. The paper trail that leads to the heart
of Lincoln's evolving presidency.  Behind the war room,
in 1862, year of decisions,
we make the acquaintence of generals George McClellan and Ulysses S. Grant.
It's a year of trial for the nation, and of tragedy for the Lincolns
who lose their son, Willie, that February.  Here, visitors can also experience a typical
day in Lincoln's presidency.
We hope to display furniture and additional original artifacts
associated with President and Mrs. Lincoln.  Next
comes Freedom Road.  As the military situation deteriorates,
Lincoln realizes that what began as a war over State's Rights
must be finished as a war for Human Rights.  Changes in his thinking are
dramatized
through a developing relationship with Frederick Douglass.  A video offers
testimony that as the first African-American invited to the White
House,
Douglass pressed Lincoln to make good on the promise of emancipation.
As the visitor makes his way around the circle of Lincoln's presidency,
he comes to its low point early in 1863.
Following the battles of Fredericksburg and Chancellorsville,
the President observes, "If there's a worse place than hell,
then I'm in it."  Lincoln's favorite means of escaping that hell
is the theater.  Here in a recreated theater box,
we consider his love of the stage, particularly his fondness for
Shakespearean tragedy.
We also learn about an eerie encounter with his future assassin
on the Washington stage.  1863 is a moment when Lincoln's war and presidency
begin to turn.
Visitors encounter a revolving door of Union generals which ultimately produces
Ulysses S. Grant,
a modern warrior who will lead the North to victory.  It's also the year when
Lincoln establishes his position at Gettysburg
as the greatest of all presidential communicators.
By contrast, in 1864, war weariness overtakes the North and threatens
Lincoln's prospects for a second term.
Passing through the wartime election, we usher visitors toward a reproduction of
Mary Surratt's boarding house.  Here, they come face to face
with the Booth conspirators, life-sized and ghostly white.
Here, we find Booth's 44 caliber single shot derringer
and other valuable pieces from the National Park Service collection of
assassination-related artifacts.
We hope to add revolving displays of items related to Booth and his
conspiracy,
loaned by private collectors.  Leaving the boarding house,
one stands before the inaugural platform as Lincoln takes the oath of office for
the second time.
He, too, has come full circle.  Above all in his attitudes about slavery,
and the meaning of the war, this becomes plain in his trip to the former
Confederate capital of Richmond,
and in his April 11th speech endorsing some form of suffrage
for former slaves.  In the audience on the White House grounds that night,
John Wilkes Booth mutters, "That's the last speech he'll ever make."
Standing 6 feet tall, we see the famous poster,
advertising Laura Keene in Our American Cousin.
From here, a stairway leads to a long, sloping hall
which will illustrate a timeline beginning at 8 a.m.
on the morning of April 14th, 1865.  On one side of
the hall, visitors can trace Abraham Lincoln's final day.
On the other, the actions of his assassin,
up to the hour when the presidential carriage sets off
for Ford's Theatre.
(music continues with sounds of a horse carriage)
(music plays)
(Actors talking) "An odd sort of destiny on the stage.  A story must play out all the way..."  Visitors can now
enter the theater and experience the events of the night of April 14th, 1865
as interpreted by the National Park Service and the Ford's Theatre Society.
The theater auditorium, a renowned  and beautiful replica of the theater
as it was on the night of the assassination will remain at the center
of the visitor's experience
of Ford's Theatre.
(music plays)
Afterwards, visitors cross 10th Street to the Peterson House
and the death chamber in which this great American story
came to its tragic end the following morning.  Here,
visitors pause to absorb the scene and setting
of such a great loss to our nation.  And of course,
the story continues beyond that fateful day.
(music plays)
Visitors enter the new Education Center by
elevator to the fourth floor.  A brief soundtrack prepares them for
the aftermath.  Exiting the elevator, they find themselves on a Washington Street
amid the sound of tolling bells on the morning of April 15th.
They are waking up to dreadful news conveyed by huge blown up newspapers
as well as the sound of newsboys on the corner.  The street leads to a rail
station
with the full-scale recreation of the presidential funeral train
as well as a large map of the route from Washington to Springfield.
Visitors looking inside the train view the President's casket
along with historic images illustrating the vast pageant of grief
that lasted twenty days.  Turning the corner, we come to the talking newspaper
which introduces us to the new president, Andrew Johnson.
The rest of this gallery is devoted to the chase for Lincoln's assassins,
culminating in a three-dimensional recreation of the burning barn where
Booth is finally cornered and killed
followed by the capture and trial of his coconspirators.
On the other side of a brick prison wall, visitors confronted gallows
and suspended mid-air a scrim, containing the images of Mary Surratt and
the others executed with her a few short weeks
after Lincoln's death.  At the end of the gallery, visitors take a winding
staircase to find a seemingly
endless tower of books symbolic of our ongoing fascination with the man about
whom the last word will never be written.
A metaphor for the evolving image and influence of America's 16th president,
the books are also an architectural component that serves to unite
four floors of exhibits and public spaces. From here,
visitors take the staircase to the third floor and an exhibit
entitled, "Legacies."  Along the way, they learn about reconstruction without
Lincoln,
a time when Northern sacrifice was squandered and the rights of newly
freed slaves tossed aside.
Moving into the gallery, we come to a glass wall,
etched with Lincoln's words arguably his most powerful legacy.
His words are both the first and last thing visitors to this gallery will
experience.
On the right, they find a short video, "The America that Might Have Been."
Lincoln scholars like David Herbert Donald and Doris Kearns Goodwin
speculate
about how our history might have been different had Lincoln not gone to Ford's
that night.
Another enduring part to the Lincoln legacy
is the strong presidency embodied at the turn of the 20th century by Theodore
Roosevelt and Woodrow Wilson.
Dedicated in 1922, the Lincoln memorial was intended to commemorate a lifelong
over.  In fact, it almost immediately became a very contemporary gathering
place for Americans
to both celebrate and occasionally protest their society.
The centerpiece of this gallery is a 24-foot wide recreation of the memorial,
with multiple screens introducing us to the great singer, Marian Anderson,
who performed there in 1939 after being turned away from Washington's
Constitution Hall.
And then, a quarter-century later, Dr.  Martin Luther King,
on the centennial of the Emancipation Proclamation,
delivering his immortal, "I Have a Dream" speech.
(music plays)
In the next section of the gallery, we address recent controversies
arising out of Lincoln's views on race and civil liberties
at wartime.  Finally, we project the Lincoln legacy
into the unknown future with a wall of children's drawings,
constantly refreshed by young visitors to the site.
Overhead, the bank of screens enables children to share their thoughts about
what Lincoln means to them.
Approaching the staircase leading down to the second floor,
visitors encounter these words from the great scholar and activist,
W.E.B. Dubois, "I love him not because he was perfect,
but because he was not, and yet, triumphed."
The second floor holds the leadership gallery, a multi-purpose space where we
can examine in greater detail,
particular aspects of Lincoln's leadership as a lawyer,
prairie politician, military strategist, or public advocate.
We may, one day, join forces with other institutions.  Imagine teaming up with the
Churchill Museum in London,
or the nation's presidential libraries, or West Point,
or National Park Service sites around the nation.  The possibilities are limited
only by our resources
and our imagination.  When this gallery is not in use as an exhibit hall,
it can serve as a reception venue, a lecture hall, or extension of the
proposed educational classroom on the building's fifth floor.
One final scroll down the staircase and around the tower of books
brings us to the first floor of retail area, the Emporium.
Here, as elsewhere throughout the complex, we have sought to break down traditional
barriers between functions.
A large stovepipe hat, for example, serves as an information desk.
In the area devoted to the sale of DVD's and other videos,
visitors are exposed to Hollywood's Lincoln where Henry Fonda,
Raymond Massey, and Gregory Peck share the silver screen
with a time traveling Lincoln in Bill and Ted's Excellent Adventure.
The new Ford's Theatre visitor experience and campus
will provide a great center of learning, reflection,
and inspiration.  The upcoming Lincoln Bicentennial affords a once-in-a
lifetime opportunity
to rediscover the complex man who remains,
after a century and a half, the American president
against whom all others are measured.
(music continues to play)
